binding.literal: In the 20th Century, the liberation and reunification with Greece took place. During the first period (1898-1960) saw the renaissance of traditional pottery. Demand rose in step with the economic revival and the free movement of goods and money. The production of storage jars, beehives, basins, jugs etc. flourished. Small vessels, on the other hand, were gradually reduced and replaced by new mass-produced materials such as glass, aluminium and iron. Certain traditional decorative elements were preserved: stamping with a serrated wheel, incision with a small fine comb, and a simplified form of clay decoration used only on jugs. The beginning of the second period (1960-2006) coincided with the post-war radical change in living standards in Greece, a country whose current borders were only determined in 1910. Crete, like other border regions, entered modern material culture. In 1960 the travelling potters stopped their annual peregrinations across the whole island and small pottery centres ceased production. The large centres, such as the villages of Thrapsano and Margarites, continued to make use of water such as water jars, basins, flowerpots and storage jars (pithoi) until 1980. From 1980 to the present day they have turned to mass production of traditional and other vessels for tourists or for use as decoration, most of which are exported to Western Europe where they are very popular, particularly pithoi. Production methods remain more or less the same, but not the clays and firing in the kiln.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: In the Ottoman Rule and Modern Times (1669 CE - Present), production in Crete declined significantly. However, traditional Cretan pottery continued to be made in small workshops, primarily for household purposes. The pottery was often characterised by its simplicity and earthy tones. In the 20th century, there was a revival of interest in Cretan pottery, with artisans incorporating traditional techniques and designs into their work. During the first phase of the Turkish Occupation, 1645-1898, biscuit ware with clay slip continued to be used, but glazed ware became rarer and coloured exclusively a light green. At the same time, characteristic two-coloured plates were imported from Rhodes. The larger vessels, particularly storage jars, continued to flourish due to the high production of olive oil during the 18th century. However, their decoration too was reduced. During the second phase of the Turkish Occupation (1770-1898), the constant armed Cretan risings against the Turks created deep social and financial insecurity. All types of production were drastically reduced and limited to essentials necessary to survival. Glazed ware was no longer produced and all other types of pottery were only present in their simplest forms.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Potters were divided into specialist pithos makers or pitharades and those who produced smaller shapes. Their indispensable assistants were the clay digger (homatas), who recognised and excavated the layers of clay, and the kiln minder (kaminiaris) who regulated the kiln heat during the firing of the pots. This was a great responsibility, as traditional kilns had no thermometers or heat gauges and any mistake during the 10-12 hours of firing meant that the whole batch would be ruined.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: In the two larger Pottery Centres the potters formed guilds, small groups of six known as takimi who scattered across the whole island from April to September. Each group would work for the whole period in a specific countryside location with a source of clay, water and a kiln, away from any villages. The seasonal migration of the guild group was called the vendema (Italian for vintage or harvest), because each year the potters chose an area where there would be a good olive harvest (vendema) and therefore the growers would need pithoi, the most lucrative type of ceramic to make.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Four Pottery Centres were established in Crete at the beginning of the second millennium, one in each prefecture. The reasons for this distribution and choice of location are not known, as there are rich sources of clay everywhere in Crete.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The Pottery Centres were villages where only part of the population was involved in ceramics, while the profession did not necessarily pass exclusively from father to son. Potters and Cretans in general considered it to be one of the worst crafts to exercise, due to the constant exposure to mud and the low income.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The Region of Murcia has a great historical tradition in wood carving, particularly in the realm of carving thrones, altarpieces, and religious figures. However, in the past, the region lacked a significant number of local sculptors, which occasionally required hiring professionals from other regions.

binding.name: o
binding.literal:
The connection with Granadian artists became evident by the end of the 16th century, with names like Alonso Cano and Pedro de Mena becoming linked to Murcia thanks to works such as an Inmaculada Concepción or a San José y San Antonio, which can be found in the parish church of San Nicolás de Bari in Murcia. The Cathedral Museum keeps works by Juan Sánchez Cordoba, the busts of San Pedro and San Pablo, a sculptor related to Mena's workshop. Cordoba conducted work for different parts of the region such as Mula, Alcantarilla and Lorca. The work of Cordoba has the kindness of the Granada schools, even debtors of the Renaissance, something coarse in execution and away from what Murcia will later consider the great sculpture of the Baroque.
In 1688 the sculptor Nicolás de Bussy was established in Murcia where he performed the well-known work of the Christ of the Blood, of the Parish of Carmen, the work of singular iconography in which a crucified Christ seems to walk while an angel picks up in a glass his beautiful blood.
The continuous arrival of artists of other nationalities, without depending on court mediation, is one of the peculiarities of the Mediterranean regions and was responsible for the formation and development of a local school.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Among all the Murcian carvers, Francisco Salzillo stands out. Francisco Salzillo is the most captivating Baroque figure in the history of art in Murcia. His craftsmanship in wood carving is unparalleled, and his mastery in handling materials, stucco, and polychrome and gilding techniques is undeniable. Besides Salzillo’s exquisite craftmantship, his works were endowed with an artistic quality that transformed traditional religious imagery into a true spectacle for the senses.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Since ancient times, Yecla has enjoyed a great reputation in wood craftsmanship. One of the earliest woodcraft professions to emerge in Yecla would be ‘aperaores’ or ‘Master Cartwrights’, as in the 16th-century there were more than 500 wood carts, meaning there were many citizens engaged in wood cart making.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: In the 17th century, only wealthy individuals could afford furniture in their homes. In the early 17th century, Yecla had five carpenters, with only two remaining by the middle of the century. For seven years, apprentices provided unpaid labour and had to travel to other towns to obtain their master carpenter's title. Not until 1690 were held examinations in Yecla.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The 18th century was a turning point for furniture, as it was gradually introduced into every home. In the early 19th century, there are records of seventeen carpenters and two woodcarvers, including their apprentices, in Yecla. It appears that there were no professional unions at that time, so there were few apprentices who chose to undergo examinations to become a craftsman master upon completing their apprenticeships., To achieve such recognition, they were forced to seek opportunities in more industrialised localities. Among all the woodworkers of this era, José Mora Parra known as 'Maestro Mora.' stands out. He was a fine artisan dedicated to artistic woodwork mostly and religious art, but he also manufactured some furniture.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: In the last century, Yecla underwent a significant development in cabinetmaking, evolving from a small workshop to a robust industry. By 1915, there were already seventy-seven professionals in the city, including woodworkers and cabinetmakers, meaning a substantial growth in this sector.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: In woodwork workshops, there have always been craftsmen who mastered wood carving. However, it is only in the early 20th century that a fine wood carving artisan appeared: José Villanueva. Mainly devoted to artistic and religious carpentry, his great expertise was passed on to many local artisans. Several factors influence events prior to the arrival in Yecla of the Valencian artisan José Martínez Altabella. His personality proves to be decisive, as it rekindles an interest in aesthetic and artistic development. Consequently, the carving workshops that he established represent a paradigm shift in the local economy.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: At the end of the 1940s, after the Spanish Civil War, there was a major crisis in the sector. The Parish Priest of Basilica of La Purísima, José Esteban Díaz, managed to establish the Furniture Worker's Cooperative "Esteban Díaz" (C.O.M.E.D.), with the participation of more than 80 families, The C.O.M.E.D. employed up to 150 workers.

binding.name: o
binding.literal:
By 1950, Yecla witnessed the proliferation of woodcarvers due to the growing demand for carving work on furniture. It was precisely these woodcarvers who led the creation of new industries. Initially, they started as expanded workshops, but with the arrival of the Furniture Fair, first held in 1961, they received a boost to start a true industrial journey. Numerous industrial buildings were constructed on the outskirts of the city, giving rise to the various industrial estates that today constitute Yecla's thriving industry.
By the 1960s, communications had greatly improved―specialised magazines abounded, books were continuously published, and fairs were inaugurated, among other developments. These circumstances opened a very encouraging future for anyone looking to prosper within the sector.
In every cultural and social progress, there have always been notable protagonists. In Yecla, the woodcarver and sculptor Pedro Ortega takes on this role. In his workshop, he had the first carving machine of German origin. Although not highly perfected, it provided significant assistance by speeding up the production process, smoothing and preparing the pieces for the finishing phase. This enhanced the creativity of the woodcarver, freeing up his hands to craft more highly ornamental pieces and even small sculptures.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: What happened in Ortega's workshop eventually influenced other workshops. The introduction of this machine into carvings spurred artisans in Yecla to venture beyond pure ornamentation and pursue deeper artistic goals. This was their evolution and their reality mainly from 1960 to 1968, but also beyond 1980. At present, the art of wood carving in Yecla does not enjoy the splendour it used to in the past. Many of the traditional skills have been lost over time, and the trend is towards a less baroque style, characterized by simpler and more contemporary lines. Despite this evolution, it is essential to recognize the importance of recovering and preserving this valuable craftsmanship. Woodcraft is not only a testament to local and regional history but also a manifestation of human creativity and skill. In an increasingly mass-produced world, it is crucial to create a space to appreciate and value the uniqueness and artistry found in each hand-carved piece, thus reaffirming the need to conserve and revitalize this tradition.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Porcelain slowly evolved in China and was finally achieved (depending on the definition used) at some point about 2,000 to 1,200 years ago; it slowly spread to other East Asian countries, then to Europe, and eventually to the rest of the world. Its manufacturing process is more demanding than that for earthenware and stoneware, the two other main types of pottery, and it has usually been regarded as the most prestigious type of pottery for its delicacy, strength, and its white colour. It combines well with both glazes and paint, and can be modelled very well, allowing a huge range of decorative treatments in tableware, vessels, and figurines. It also has many uses in technology and industry.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The European name, porcelain in English, comes from the old Italian porcellana (cowrie shell) because of its resemblance to the surface of the shell. Porcelain is also referred to as china or fine china in some English-speaking countries, as it was first seen in imports from China during the 17th century. Properties associated with porcelain include low permeability and elasticity; considerable strength, hardness, whiteness, translucency, and resonance; and a high resistance to corrosive chemicals and thermal shock.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The first mention of porcelain in Europe is in Il Milione by Marco Polo in the 13th century. In the 14th century, the explorer brought a small jar from China back to Europe with him and Chinese porcelain became a favourite among royalty. During the sixteenth century, the Portuguese and Dutch established commercial trade routes to China and the European market for porcelain grew fast. China kept porcelain’s ingredients and production process a closely guarded secret, inspiring scientists across Europe to experiment with materials and formulas.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Apart from copying Chinese porcelain in faience (tin glazed earthenware), the soft-paste Medici porcelain in 16th-century Florence was the first real European attempt to reproduce it, with little success. Early in the 16th century, Portuguese traders returned home with samples of kaolin, which they discovered in China to be essential in the production of porcelain wares. However, the Chinese techniques and composition used to manufacture porcelain were not yet fully understood. Countless experiments to produce porcelain had unpredictable results and met with failure. In the German state of Saxony, the search concluded in 1708 when Ehrenfried Walther von Tschirnhaus produced a hard, white, translucent type of porcelain specimen with a combination of ingredients, including kaolin and alabaster, mined from a Saxon mine in Colditz. It was a closely guarded trade secret of the Saxon enterprise.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: In 1712, many of the elaborate Chinese porcelain manufacturing secrets were revealed throughout Europe by the French Jesuit father Francois Xavier d'Entrecolles and soon published in the Lettres édifiantes et curieuses de Chine par des missionnaires jésuites. The secrets, which d'Entrecolles read about and witnessed in China, were now known and began seeing use in Europe.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The first European porcelain factory was established in Saxony in 1710 after kaolin was discovered nearby. In the early 18th century Marquise de Pompadour began importing from China and manufacturing porcelain in France. 'Manufacture De Sevres' began near Paris and became the largest porcelain distributor in Europe. Imported Chinese porcelains were held in such great esteem in Europe that in English china became a commonly–used synonym for the Italian-derived porcelain.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Experiments at Rouen produced the earliest soft-paste in France, but the first important French soft-paste porcelain was made at the Saint-Cloud factory before 1702. Soft-paste factories were established with the Chantilly manufactory in 1730 and at Mennecy in 1750. The Vincennes porcelain factory was established in 1740, moving to larger premises at Sèvres[43] in 1756. Vincennes soft-paste was whiter and freer of imperfections than any of its French rivals, which put Vincennes/Sèvres porcelain in the leading position in France and throughout the whole of Europe in the second half of the 18th century.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Originally the white substance used to make the fine porcelain referred to as Limoges was discovered by a chemist's wife in 1765 in hopes of being used as a soap. In St. Yrieixin a town near Limoges France the substance was identified as a pure form of Kaolin. The soil of the area surrounding Limoges is rich in deposits of kaolin and feldspar, the essential ingredients for hard paste porcelain.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The manufacturing of hard-paste porcelain at Limoges was established by Turgot in 1771 following the discovery of local supplies of kaolin and a material similar to petuntse in the economically distressed area at Saint-Yrieix-la-Perche, near Limoges. The materials, which were quarried beginning in 1768, were used to produce hard-paste porcelain similar to Chinese porcelain.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: In 1768, a chemist’s wife in St. Yrieixin, a commune just outside of Limoges in southwest-central France, made a thrilling discovery: A soft white substance in the soil. At first, the story goes, the woman thought the substance could be used to wash and bleach linen, but it turned out she had stumbled upon “white gold.” The substance was kaolin, a rare and precious white clay that is a key ingredient in crafting fine porcelain. That discovery set Limoges on a path towards becoming a centre for some of the most beautiful and coveted porcelain in the world. The first porcelain with the Limoges mark was produced in 1771. Limoges had all the essential natural ingredients needed to create world-class porcelain—kaolin, feldspar and quartz—but, just as importantly, the region had a vibrant history of craftsmanship that dated back nearly a millennium. In the 12th century, Limoges was the most famous European centre of vitreous enamel production, known as Opus de Limogia or Labor Limogiae. Limoges also produced faience earthenware, or fine in-glazed pottery. The heritage of ceramics and decoration was deeply woven into the fabric of the city.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: In 1771 Limoges, one of the oldest towns in the French kingdom rapidly began constructing manufacturing facilities with wood burning kilns for the production of fine porcelain. The first porcelain with the Limoges mark was produced in 1771. The name of the city of Limoges has become synonymous with the high quality porcelain products manufactured by those early companies. The hand painting and decorating of Limoges porcelains was done by factory approved hired artists as well as other professional and unprofessional artists.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: A manufactory at Limoges was placed under the patronage of the comte d'Artois, brother of Louis XVI, and was later purchased by the King in 1784, apparently with the idea of producing hard-paste bodies for decoration at Sèvres, although this never happened. After the French Revolution a number of private factories were established at Limoges, including Bernardaud, Haviland & Co. and Royal Limoges.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: After the French Revolution, the restrictions on porcelain production were lifted and the commercial trade flourished. In 1819, the region had four porcelain factories; by 1900, there were 35 factories and 120 kilns employing up to 8,000 workers. Limoges became the undisputed French capital of porcelain production, as well as a major exporter of porcelain to the U.S.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Limoges porcelain is known for its dazzling white, luminous hue and the intricacy of its hand-painted decorations. Popular design styles included Rococo-style figures; exotic birds, flowers, and marine subjects on bright colour backgrounds; minute patterns embellished in gold; and narrative scenes from classical mythology and pastoral life.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Limoges porcelain continues to signal luxury and refinement. Limoges objects and dinnerware collections are commissioned by presidents and royalty and passed down through generations in families, but the industry continues to push creative boundaries that maintain porcelain’s relevance.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Limoges is also home to a younger generation of exciting artistic collectives like Passage Secret and Esprit Porcelaine. These workshops are using porcelain to create contemporary sculptures, fanciful lamps, and decorative household objects, like sugar bowls and goblets. They are also experimenting technically by combining porcelain with unconventional materials, like iron and sandstone.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Counterfeiting of Limoges porcelain has been documented for decades.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The storied porcelain house Bernardaud has produced cutting edge dinnerware collections with artists like Joan Miro, Marina Abramovic, Alexander Calder, Kara Walker, Julian Schnabel, and David Lynch. The house has also expanded into high-end costume jewellery and collaborated with prominent artists to make objects, such as Roy Lichtenstein’s Landscape Mobile and Jeff Koons’ balloon animals. These collaborations have given Limoges a place in the canon of modern art.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: “It was a strong emulation between our creative and technical skills that made us want to form this duo,” said the founders of Passage Secret, Yaël Malignac and Guillaume Descoings. “We want the unusual, the unexpected, poetry and beauty. We want to create contrast to highlight the porcelain, its whiteness, its fragility, its translucency.“

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Limoges maintains the position it established in the 19th century as the premier manufacturing city of porcelain in France.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: ROHL®, the luxury kitchen and bath fixtures brand, for instance, works with Limoges clay to create the Allia™ Sink Collection, fireclay sinks that have an extra thick luminous glaze to create a beautiful stain and chip resistant surface. “Limoges has such a rich history of craftsmanship and it’s been such a unique and rewarding experience to work with these artisans who have perfected their work over the years,” says Lou Rohl, chairman and founder of House of ROHL.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Limoges porcelain has always married the beautiful with the functional. Some applications of porcelain draw on the material’s unique properties of strength, durability, and imperviousness to create products that enhance everyday life. Thanks to its unique geologic and design history, Limoges is a global centre that showcases all the possibilities of what porcelain can be.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Today, Limoges is classified as a UNESCO Creative City and the ceramics industry continues to thrive. It’s a region where history and tradition inform modern design. From decorative boxes to exquisite dinnerware to elegant kitchen sinks, Limoges porcelain remains a world-class standard for craftsmanship.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Nikiforos Phokas freed Crete from the Arabs. He became concerned about the low moral standing and religious beliefs of the population after 137 years of Arab rule. There was unrest by the local population against the new Byzantine administration.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Geometric textiles came to Crete in 1092 with the 12 Byzantine rulers and their families. The Emperor Alexios II Comnenos, disturbed by the continuing unrest in Crete, sent twelve prominent Byzantine families to Crete to re-establish strong links with Constantinople and improve the religious, moral and economic standards of the community.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The standard designs were passed down from generation to generation, and the designs were passed on to the people and thus became a tradition and popular heritage for the weavers of Crete in the following centuries, and the common artistic stock of the place.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: All women draw from the same stock, and although each of them may think she is creating something new, in reality her ingenuity is limited to slight variations on the themes of tradition. A completely new and original creation does not exist in the weaving tradition, nor in folk art in general. Because it is very difficult, almost impossible, for the common man to overcome the limitations imposed on him by the artistic tradition of his place, limitations of technique, style, expression, technique.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Nikiforos Phokas prompted the Emperor Alexios I Comninos, towards the end of the 11th century, to send a number of prominent Byzantine families from Constantinople to settle in Crete to improve the control over the local population and raise the moral and religious standards in the island. Their arrival has been known for centuries as that of the story of the twelve Archondopoula (young rulers).

binding.name: o
binding.literal: In a document, called the “Chrysovoulo”, a document sealed with gold to authenticate the Emperor’s signature, the Emperor, after threatening the Cretans with severe punishment if they were not to fully submit to his will, said that he was sending them as king and trustee his son, Isaakion, together with twelve Archondes.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Large areas of Crete were allocated to each of these families and their names are reflected today as place names in numerous locations in Crete, such as Skordilo in Sitia, also in Mylopotamos near Rethymnon, Kallergiana in Kissamos next to Kastelli, and Kallergo near Rethymnon, there is also a Kallergis mountain peak in the White Mountains, and many other locations are reflecting the names of the Archondopoula with the location name either ending in –ana, e.g. Kallergiana or using the possessive “of…”, e.g.“tou Kallergi”or “tou Skordili”.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Their family crests can also be found on churches and monuments all over Crete and members of these families are prominent members of today’s Greek community. The same names appear numerous times in Crete’s turbulent history over the next few centuries as many of them played prominent roles in great historical events.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Preservation of Byzantine patterns in Cretan woven fabrics. Weaving tradition passed down through generations, becoming a tradition and folk heritage for Cretan women weavers

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Textiles with geometric decoration are woven across Crete, with regional variations and particular features in each area.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Geometrical designs adorn fabrics used for household purposes and decoration, such as various bedspreads, wall hangings, sofa covers etc., as well as textiles necessary for outdoor work, such as “sintzandedes” (saddle-cloths) and the drouvades and vouryies (bags) used by Cretan farmers and shepherds until recently.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Due to their use, woven fabrics with geometrical designs are usually woollen, or more precisely of wool and cotton: the warp threads are woollen, while the connecting wefts are cotton.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: In “xobliasta” woven fabrics, also known as “embroidery on the loom”, the decoration is woven on the loom at the same time as the fabric. This weaving technique is complicated, time-consuming and requires great care and attention. To create the decorative motifs, the weaver passes the coloured weft, wound into small skeins, through the warps by hand. As different coloured wefts alternate in each row, the weaver must judge the length of each colour line carefully, counting the number of warp threads. New measurements are needed for the next row, as the decorative patterns are created by increasing or decreasing the length of each colour line, moving the line, eliminating it or creating new ones. As the weaving progresses the patterns appear. Between them is visible the background colour, the “ground”. This is shuttle-woven. Usually the different wefts of each colour in the same row are not connected to each other but simply run alongside, covering two adjacent warps. In this case, small interruptions appear in the weave. When the lines of the design parallel to the warp are large, the wefts are intermeshed to make the weave continuous. This is difficult and time-consuming work. Another way to achieve the same result is to pass the two adjacent wefts through the same warp, but this results in a slightly crooked line.In Cretan woven fabrics, decorative patterns with lines at right angles to the weave are rare. Usually the pattern lines are oblique, as the basic motif is the diamond.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Such textiles have not been woven for years, and few old examples are left. They have been bought by peddlers and sold outside Crete, or even abroad. These textiles are not only beautiful, rich and varied; they are unique, both as to the weaving technique and as to their features.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Although the weaving of tapestry has been dated back to the ancient Egyptians, we start herein the origins of French tapestry dating from the 11th Century.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The Bayeux Tapestry is the only masterpiece of it's kind in the world and is a historical record retracing the events leading to the conquest of England, and culminating with the Battle of Hastings in 1066 by William the Conqueror.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The story of the tapestry begins in 1064. The tapestry is in reality a hand embroidery on linen cloth using wools of various colours. The tapestry is 70 metres long and 1/2 metre high, and was most probably woven in an Anglo-Saxon workshop supervised by Odeon de Conteville, Bishop of Bayeux and half brother of William the Conqueror.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The subject matter of tapestries from this period is characterized by extreme awkwardness of design, proportion, perpective and detail. The designs translated into the medium of tapestry from this period appear quite primitive and childlike, especially when compared to the masterpieces of the 16th-18th Centuries.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The two scenes in the fragment represent two months of the year - April, which is legible on the top left and is symbolised by a man holding a hflower next to a tree upon which two birds are climbing. The month of May was the "warring" month and is depicted by a horseman wearing a helmet, coat of chain mail and carrying a lance and shield.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Les Mois de'Lannee (depicted below) is a surviving fragment of a late 12th Century tapestry from Baldishol Church in Norway and is a wonderful example of awkwardness of transposition of 12th Century design into the medium of tapesty and is one of the oldest surviving tapestries in the western world.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The use of tapestries at this time was more for practicality than that of artistic, decorative or comemorative value. Kings and Lords traveling from one castle to another were fond of tapestries, for when rolled up they could carried and hung on the walls of various residences for protection from the cold and noise in the large rooms, most of which were damp and noisy as the windows were without glass and the floors were paved with flagstone.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Canopy beds originated from the custom whereby tapestries would form small comfortable areas within a room amidst the coldness of stone and in which it was possible to sleep in warmth. When a guest would arrive, usually in a common hall, the Lord's room was immediatley "dressed": a canopy for his bed was arranged and cross-walls of tapestry placed north or south to protect against cold in winter or warmth in summer.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: When the Lord's moved into a new castle they would not hesitate to have a tapestry cut so as to facilitate a door opening. Whenever the ceiling of a room was too low to hang the tapestry at full length, the bottom of the tapestry would be cut-off, which was kept and then sewn onto another tapestry found too small - even if the theme and colours were different.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Such 13th Century tapestries, a small number which survive today still continue to puzzle historians.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Up until the Hundred Years War (1337-1453), France was the most important producer of tapestries and Paris was the undisputed capital. Tapestry design had evolved from the extreme awkwardness of the 12th Century, however movement, proportion, perspective and composition were still cumbersome and the tapestries were composed of improbable associations of the subject matter.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The tapestry above - Bataille et Embarquement (of unknown origin), depicts a combat that is most likely drawn for the Iliad, and shows Knights, archers and mercenaries in battle with a galleon in the background that is reproduced in such a amnner as to appear on land. In the foreground, Royal people are depicted with composed dispositions amid a chaotic battle scene. The tapestry is on display in the Cluny Museum, Paris.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The 100 Years War and the systematic plundering of Paris sent the tapestry makers fleeing northwards to Arras (Ateliers d'Arras), where they set-up their tapestry studios.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The tapestry depicted left, Offrande du Coer, is attributed to the Arras workshops 1400-1410 and is currently at the Cluny Museum in Paris. This tapestry depicts a finely dressed young man offering his heart to his favourite - a tapestry expressing an atmosphere of tenderness and affection.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Towards the end of the Hundred Years War (1337-1453), the pillaging of Arras in 1446 by Louis XI sent the tapestry manufacturers towards Flanders which became the tapestry centre.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The tapestry craftsmen, working in family concerns whose manufactuing skills were passed down from father to son, had to possess skills not only of weavers but also of dyers, the two skils being interrelated, and a knowledge of which was necessary in order to bring a successful conclusion to the tapestry. Their secret lay in the skillfulness in extracting colours from various plants and incorporating them into the wool. This method gave them a palette of only 12 colours from which to work (modern computer screens have 16 million colours).

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Materials used in the weaving of the tapestries were Arras thread, (aka Picardy wool), Italian silk, and silver and gold threads from Cyprus. Tapestry manufacture was slow, taking a skilled worker about two months to weave a square foot (approx. 30 cm square).

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Many large tapestries were a group effort, each worker having his own particular portion of the tapestry to weave which would be joined at a later date. This lead to the weave having different tensions and techniques within the one tapestry - some portions of the tapestry more taught than others.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The tapestry makers wove biblical scenes and at a later date, scenes from mythology; taking their inspiration from the translations of Greek and Latin texts. The lives of saints were widley represented and the background was either a temple, palace or simply a solid colour. The costumes were seldom of the era depicted in the scene, more often borrowed from colourful biblical illustrations.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: These picturesque anachronisms gave a particular charm to the tapestries of the 15th Century, also known as Gothic tapestries and later as Flemish Gothic tapestries. The composition of the tapetries depicted an awkwardness in perspective and landscape backgrounds. It was to be the next century before the genius of a Raphael was to bring tapestry to the true art of composition.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The purchaser of the tapestry usually dictated the subject, size, number of pieces, themes, subject manner and attitudes. Working in close collaboration with the tapestry worker was a a painter who created the preliminary designs or paintings, within the restriction of the palette of colours of the threads available to the tapestry weavers.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The tapestry below Suzanne et les Viellards (Marmattan Museum, Paris) is a fine example of a biblical scene. All the vitality of this work lies in the expression of the faces. Clothes make up a superb symphony in which reds, blues and golds are blended in the purest Gothic style.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Towards the end of the 15th Century, continuing into the 16th Century, the Loire Valley (Southeast France) became a popular place for tapestry makers as it was the favoured area of the French Aristocracy for their country retreats. Rural scenes with freshness and charm, where gentle ladies, lords and peasant folk are depicted on a flowery or "mille fleur" (thousand flower) background of the Loire Valley.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The garments of the people depicted in the tapesries were seldom in accord with history and time, often imitating the court garments that were fashionable at the time. The subjects were adorned with gold and their garments were trimmed with exquisite fabrics and furs, even the peasants appear like aristocracy. As most documnets concerning tapestries of the 14th-16th centuries no longer exist, experts generally refer to the costumes of the subjects to establish the date of execution.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Le Berger tapestry, is an interesting tapestry because two components of its content are influenced by the style of two periods from the 15th century. The captions at the top and the right of the tapestry are of the early 15th Century Flemish Gothic style and the flowers at the shepherd's feet are of the style "mille fleur" (mid 15th - early 16th century).

binding.name: o
binding.literal: La Danse tapestry is part of the famous set of the "Noble Pastorale" series of tapestries created around the mid 15th century and is characteristic of the tapestries made by the manufacturers of the Loire Valley. The background is entirely Mille Fleur.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The tapestries Le Gout ("taste") and A Mon Seul Desir ("my only desire" ) are two tapestries from within the famous set of six Lady and the Unicorn tapestries on display in a purpose buit room within the Cluny Museum in Paris.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: At the end of the middle ages, epic subjects became popular. Tapetries illustrated kings and princes in tournament, combat scenes and hunting parties. This period remains the most prolific for unrivalled masterpieces.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The tapestry Le Depart pour la Chasse, (below) aka "Plaisante Chasse" or "Chasse de Volerie", depicts hawking, a favourite pass-time of the lords of the period. Thought to have been the cration of Flanderine workshops (C1500), this medieval masterpiece today adorns the vaulted rooms of the Cluny Museum in Paris.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: A lord setting off on a hunt is distinguished by his highly decorated coat and his light coloured horse as he rides away from his chateau. His leather gaiters protect his calves from being scratched by the undergrowth.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: After the Italian Wars, the Renaissance radically changed the art of tapestry making. The new aesthetic form was an association of painting and tapestry. Around 1530, Francis I founded the first Royal tapestry workshop at Fontainbleau in France. The great Italian artist, Le Primatice was the chief painter and decorator.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Associating painting with tapestry Raphael introduced the art of composition, order, clarity, perspective and light. Raphael's work translated into a series of ten very famous tapestries known as the Acts of the Apostles, for the Sistine Chapel in the Vatican, Rome. The primary purpose of the paintings produced by Raphael was to be used as templates (or blueprints) by weavers for producing the tapestries and these paintings are known as "cartoons". The Raphael cartoons have become as famous as the tapestries themselves. Raphael was commissioned in 1515 by the Medici Pope Leo X (1513-21) to produce the works and are the oldest surviving cartoons on paper.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Many of the cartoons by celebrated artists were later re-joined and have become valuable artifacts in their own right.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: At the time of the Italian Wars, and with the Renaissance and the arrival of Italian artists, tapestry radically changed style.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The weavers worked on the back of the tapestry, producing a mirror image of the cartoon, which therefore had to be designed in reverse.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: In 1517 Raphael's cartoons were sent to Brussles for weaving in the workshops of Peter Van Aelst and were finished around 1521. The tapestries were woven on a low-warp loom (or basse-lisse technique) whereby the cartoons were cut into strips by the weavers and placed beneath the warp (vertical) threads of the loom, following the design with the coloured threads of the weft (left to right). The width of the strips was limited by both the size of the loom and by the arm-span of the weavers working side by side, with their cartoon strip placed next to their colleagues.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The tapestry Retour de Chasse depicts a lord, accompanied by his beaters, is returning to his property seen in the distance. The tapestry holds all that characterizes Renaissance art: composition, decor, perspective, light and borders of fruits, flowers and birds. The richness and elegance of the costumes in this Renaissance masterpiece contrasts with the austerity of medieval tapestries.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The tapestry Promenade Medieval is of the style that links between the Middle Ages and the Renaissance and reflects the manner of life of the period. The tapestry is a masterpiece of high quality weaving of the 16th Century.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Rich borders and arabesques characterised the highly coloured style of the Renaissance period.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Around 1660, Colbert founded the Royal Factory at Gobelins, under the name Royal Workshop of Crown Furniture and later renamed to Beauvais in 1664, under the protection of Louis XIV. By 1675, more than 800 painters and tapestry makers could be seen at the Gobelins in Paris, under the brilliant direction of Charles Le Brun, whose idea was to group artists according to various talents.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Le Brun had each artist specialize in that for which he had an affinity and gift. This is why it is not unusual to find cartoons signed by several artists. In the 17th century, the perfection of the tapestry weavers had reached it's pinnacle, the stitch had reached a maturity never before attained.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The inventory of the King's furniture at the death of Louis XIV, contained no less than 2155 Gobelins tapestries woven under the auspicious direction of Charles Le Brun.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The tapestry La Chasse au Cerf, le Rapport, (depicted above) is one of several tapestries from several series of tapestries produced over two centuries known as the Maximilien tapestries after the emperor Maximilien. The model shown above was woven in the Gobelins and hangs in the Louvre Museum in Paris.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: This was a period where the "Verdures" - themes featuring greenery and foliage rose to popularity.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The tapestry Verdure de Flandres (below), was woven in Brussels and hangs in the Museum of Art and Decoration in Paris. This work is of outstanding quality, both by it's perspective and the luxuriance of it's foliage.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: After the death of Louis XIV, (1638-1715), the formal subjects gave way to more imaginative compositions. Tapestry weaving became more romantic with beautiful landscapes: this style reaching its peak with Boucher and endured during the entire reign of Louis XV. During this time tapestries depicted sensuality, provocative nudes, voluptuousness - all set in charming landscapes, where fallen gods and erotic nymphs dance.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Leda and the Swan and Sacrifice to Cybele are two tapestry that illustrate the sensualness of 18th Century tapestries. Sacrifice to Cybele is reprodued from a painting by Jaan Breughal, depicting nymphs and peasants making offerings of fruit, flowers and crops as gestures of thanksgiving to Cybele, the godess of nature.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Tapestry techniques became greatly modified, the compositions more mannered and the themes more stylish and elegant. The leading painters of the day continued to compose tapestries as if they were paintings and gone was the practicality of useful function as in the middle ages. Tapestries were now strictly for aesthetic and decorative values.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: J.B. Leprince a student of Boucher, was one of the most well known painters at the start of the 18th Century. He created a new kind of exoticism based on the Northern Countries. With the Russian Games, six works at the Musee de L'ancien Archeveche in Aix-en-Provence, he introduced for the first time to French decoration the people, costumes and picturesque aspects of Russian life.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The tapestry below Les Marchands d'Oiseaux is typically 18th Century by its spirit, grace and easy rendering of the ambient northern light. This tapestry was executed in Beauvais in 1770.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: In 1757 Jacques de Vaucanson developed a low warp (basse-lisse) loom that was improved by Joseph Maree Jacquard (1752-1834). This loom was to be the pre-curser of the technique used in the jacquard looms of today, and increased the speed at which tapestries could be reproduced.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Weft yarns (left to right) of different colours are woven from the back of the fabric to the face of the tapestry to form the design, the purpose of which was to imitate hand woven tapestry. Today, many forms of jacquard weaves of varying qualities are incorporated into the manufacture of jacquard tapestries. Different makes of Jacquard loom impart their own "fingerprint" or look to the tapestry they produce and these tapestries usually derive their name from the place (or workshop) of manufacture eg. Halluin, Gobelin, Louvieres and Loiselles.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: At the end of the French Revolution, artistic inspiration was abandoned. The Royal Workshops became government institutions managed by civil servants and the group of foreign artists painfully assembled under Charles Le Brun was broken-up.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Vandalism, pillaging and destruction reigned everywhere with some of the most beautiful tapestries burned in order to extract the small amount of gold and silver thread used in their weaving. Others were used as wind-breaks for vineyards or shelter for street peasants and refugees. The First Empire and reign of Napoleon I brought the final downfall of the art of tapestry and no masterpiece was to emerge from this confused era.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Beauvais, Aubsusson and Fellitin re-opened in 1795 and specialized in upholstering chairs. They limited themselves by reproducing tapestries from the old designs of the great artists of the 17th & 18th Centuries, reproducing tapestries in their thousands until the 19th Century.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Tapestry design and manufacture have once again become the subject of popular decorative taste and many styles have emerged during this era.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: The Elephant tapestry, (above) although first appearing in the mid 19th Century, finds popularity at the close of the 20th Century. This tapestry is reproduced from a portion of a large tapestry that hangs in the Louvre, Paris. The original was woven in Aubusson in the middle of the 19th Century, a period where "Orientalism" was the trend.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Today "popular" tapestries are jacquard machine woven by boutique weavers in France, Belgium, Portugal, Spain, Italy, Egypt and the USA and Aubusson hand woven tapestries being woven in China. Once again tapestries are produced for their aesthetic and decorative values, in varying themes and artistic styles that are inspired from film, television, home fashion and decorating.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Petros Dellatolas has been carving marble since the age of five. He is a graduate of Pyrgos School of Fine Arts in Tinos, where he graduated in 1961, and worked in Ioannis Filippotis’ workshop until 1966. From 1969 to today, he has been working and inspiring others to create marble art at his own workshop in Spitalia on Tinos.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: He worked in Ioannis Filippotis’ workshop until 1966. From 1969 to today, he has been working and inspiring others to create marble art at his own workshop in Spitalia on Tinos.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: His full name relates to stone and marble masonry. He is a marble art sculptor who carries on the family tradition. His art has gained recognition and has been exhibited internationally. He has been creating his works in his own workshop for more than 20 years now.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Attained certification to be permanently displayed at the Children’s Museum of Indianapolis in the United States.

binding.name: o
binding.literal:
Stratis Filippotis, was born in Pyrgos but left the island at the age of 18 to study design and art at the Athens School of Fine Arts. There, he established his own workshop and a flourishing career, creating 300 iconostasis and 150 statues whose designs can be sold online.
Descendant of the great modern Greek sculptor, Dimitrios Filippotis, son of Ionnis Fillipotis and father of Ionnis S. Fillipotis
Stratis Fillipotis left the island at the age of 18 to study design and art at the Athens School of Fine Arts.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Ioannis Filippotis constructed the great bell tower of the Holy Church of Panagia Evaggelistria of Tinos (Our Lady of Tinos) between 1951 and 1956. With an imposing height of nearly 30 metres, it soars upwards in three marble compartments (lanterns), culminating in the shape of a cross. That belltower holds approximately 50 cubic metres of marble and took him five years to build. He had 30 marble carvers on his team.

binding.name: o
binding.literal:
This chemberi (headscarf) is intact. It was never worn.
There was a woman who, when she became a widow, did not want to put it on. Her mother had died wearing one. She wore it when her two brothers were murdered, and she never removed it since.
But the other woman had a job, she had to work because she had to fund the studies of her little daughter.
When the daughter passed the exams for the university, her husband was ill. What was she supposed to do? She wanted her child to go and study, she did not want to become an obstacle for her. Back then, there weren’t any cars or money. She packed her daughter’s suitcase, her husband was ill, but she took her to the bus.
She must have saved some money, as much as she could, and she sent her daughter on her own to studies. And then, when the girl got the scholarship to continue her studies in Italy, they were talking over the phone, and the mother kept telling her daughter, “I will pay the phone bill! Just keep talking, keep talking!"
This woman had a job and didn't wear the chemberi. Before her late husband died, she used to tell him, “I am not wearing it. It is your fault that you are leaving. It is not mine”.
He would reply “Don’t wear it”, as he loved her very much. She often asked him, “Why do you love me that much?”
She was made to get married, against her will.
She was a sixteen-year-old girl, when her father died. And she loved him! Oh, she loved her father very much!
For the ceremony that follows, nine months after the funeral, her two brothers and her oldest sister’s husband returned back to the village from the city. She could not imagine then that they would want her to get married, because the custom had it that the mourning period would last for years. There was a man who met her brothers and asked to marry her. She had never considered that! They say that this man used to pass by her house, but she was a young girl, how could this idea ever cross her mind!
One day her brother-in-law went to her home. She was sleeping on the sofa, at that time, while her mother and aunt were sitting around the fireplace still crying over her father’s death.
The brother-in-law entered the house saying "Dear mother, cook this meat on my behalf because we will have the little one getting married”. The girl overheard the talking but she acted like she was asleep. Her mother didn't ask anything, neither who the groom was nor what they did, nothing. Neither her mother, nor her wanted this marriage. The mother cooked the meat, as she was asked to do, gave it to them and they feasted until morning.
And what about her? Where was she? Nobody had told her the news yet.
She gets up the following morning, takes the donkey, the baskets, and there she heads off to work in their vineyard. She filled the baskets with grapes and was on her way back to the village. As she was passing by the traditional cafe there was still singing going on.
There was a lady-neighbor there, who when she saw the girl, turned to another neighbor, and said: “Is not she the one that they engaged last night? And where has she been? At the vineyard?” She went, unloaded the baskets and her face was red like fire due to her agitation. She passed by the cafe, the others were still singing. Her mother still hadn't told her a thing! Her mother would not take any initiative at all! That is how mothers were back then, they would not. In the evening they would come home for the engagement.
She was thinking to herself about leaving, to go to the city, to her sisters and uncles. She didn't have her sisters around to comfort her, to talk together and find a way for her to escape. But if she were to leave, if in the morning the groom-to-be and her siblings would meet, they would murder each other. That's how things were done back then. The groom would say, “You gave her to me and then you let her leave?” That’s what stopped her; Her concern for her brother not to be murdered. The groom, as they say, was good, he was well respected, a nice man, but he wasn't for her. Neither did she choose him, nor was she asked. She used to tell him: “Why do you love me that much?” They had four children, they lived together, and she was fifty-five years old when she lost him. Back then, mourning was a big dowry, you couldn't do it in any other way. It lasted for years! But she didn't wear the chemberi. At first, they condemned her for not wearing it. All the women in the village and her female neighbors alike. But they didn't see that she was the one who saved them all. She was the first one to stop wearing the chemberi and thereafter others could also do it and did not put it on.
She was the first one who did it, and there it ended. The other day, a girl, who lives in another country, went to meet her and told her: “Yesterday we were talking with my sisters in New York, and I mentioned your name, saying that it was you who stopped the whole chemberi thing".
This is now over! No matter if the man who dies is twenty years old, no matter if he is thirty, no matter if he is forty, women do not put the chemberi on any longer.
Nowadays, within a year they move on with their lives. What should one do? That’s life, one has to move on and also take care of themselves.
I mean, how? Women to be wearing it while they work?
In the past, mourning was held by women only. Most men, after losing their wife, were ready to get married again. They would go for another marriage, after their wife died. They would marry again, because they could not live on their own.
Women not only would not marry again, but they would also put the chemberi on, as well! For women to wear the chemberi, it meant they were not available anymore, that their life, as women, was over. They were done.
This woman was widowed at the age of fifty-five and then she did plenty of jobs for her living. She educated her children, she built up houses, worked a lot, and all out of poverty.
Other women were widowed at the age of twenty, twenty-two, twenty-five and would never marry again. Nowadays, in the case of a man’s early death the older women ask: did the widow put the chemberi on? Both those of them who didn't wear it and those who wear it, are keen to go and have it removed from her.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Αυτό το τσεμπέρι είναι αγκίνιο. Δεν φορέθηκε, ποτέ. Ήταν μια γυναίκα που όταν χήρεψε δεν ήθελε να το βάλει. Η μάνα της, πέθανε με το τσεμπέρι. Σκοτώσανε της δυο αδερφούς όταν το ‘βαλε, και έτσι επόμεινε. Η άλλη όμως είχε δουλεία, έπρεπε να δουλέψει γιατί σπούδαζε. Σπούδαζε τη κόρη της τη μικρή. Όταν πέρασε το κοπέλι στο πανεπιστήμιο ο άντρας της ήτανε άρρωστος. Πώς να το κάνει η γυναίκα; Ήθελε το παιδί της να πάει να σπουδάσει να μη το εμποδίσει. Δεν ήτανε αμάξια τότε, δεν ήτανε λεφτά. Του φτιάχνει τη βαλίτσα και το πάει στο λεωφορείο, ο άντρας της άρρωστος. Θα ‘χε μαζέψει λεφτά, ότι μπορούσε, και το βάζει και το στέλνει μοναχό του στις σπουδές. Και μετά, όταν πήρε το κοπέλι την υποτροφία για την Ιταλία μιλούσανε στο τηλέφωνο και της έλεγε συνέχεια, «εγώ θα πληρώνω το τηλέφωνο μόνο μίλιε, μίλιε». Η γυναίκα αυτή είχε δουλειά και το τσεμπέρι δε το ‘βαζε. Προτού πεθάνει ο συγχωρεμένος ο άντρας της, του ‘λεγε, «δε το βάνω γιατί φταις εσύ κ α φύγεις. Δε φταίω ‘γω» Αυτός της έλεγε να μη το βάλει, την αγαπούσε πολύ. Συχνά τον ρωτούσε «Γι’ άντα μρε μ’ αγαπάς τόσο να πολύ;». Αυτήν την παντρέψανε χωρίς να θέλει. Ήτανε κοριτσάκι 16 χρονών όταν πέθανε ο πατέρας της. Και τον αγαπούσε, πολύ τον αγαπούσε τον πατέρα της. Στα 9μηνα του, οι δυο τις αδερφοί και ένας κουνιάδος της πρώτης της αδερφής, γυρνάνε στο χωρίο από τη χώρα. Δε φαντάστηκε αυτή ότι θα τη παντρεύανε γιατί το πένθος κρατούσε χρόνια. Πήγε ένας άνθρωπος, βρήκε τους αδερφούς της και τη ζήτησε. Αυτή ούτε που το ‘χε σκεφτεί! Περνούσε λέει αυτός από το σπίτι της, αλλά αυτή ήτανε κοπέλι, πού να το σκεφτεί! Μια στιγμή πάει ο κουνιάδος της στο σπίτι, αυτή κοιμότανε στον καναπέ, καθότανε η μάνα με τη θεία στην παρασιά και κλαίγανε ακόμα τον πατέρα. Μπαίνει ο κουνιάδος και λέει «κερά μάνα, ψήσε μου αυτό το κρέας γι’ άντα επαντρέψαμε τη μικρή». Το ακούει η άλλη μα έκανε πώς κοιμότανε. Η μάνα της δεν ερώτησε τίποτα, ούτε ποιον επήρε, ποιον της δώσανε, τι κάνανε, τίποτα. Ούτε η μάνα της, μα ούτε και αυτή ήθελε να τη παντρέψουνε. Τους έψησε το κρέας, τους το ΄δωσε και αυτοί γλεντούσανε μέχρι το πρωί. Και αυτή πού ήτανε; Το νέο, δε της το ‘χανε πει ακόμη. Σηκώνεται το πρωί, παίρνει το γάιδαρο, τις κόφες και πάει μοναχή και τριγούσε το αμπέλι τους. Γέμισε τις κόφες και γυρίζει στο χωριό. Περνά από το καφενείο και αυτοί τραγουδούσανε ακόμη. Εκεί που περνούσε, ήτανε μία άλλη γειτόνισσα και λέει τις αλληνής: «μωρ’ συ! Του ‘τηνε δεν επαντρέψανε οψάργας; και πού ήτονε; Στ’ αμπέλι;» Πάει, ξεφορτώνει και η μούρη της ήτανε κατακόκκινη από τη φωτιά. Από τη ταραχή της. Περνά από το καφενείο, οι άλλοι ακόμα τραγουδούσανε. Η μάνα της ακόμη δεν της είχε πει πράμα. Δεν είχε. Δεν είχε πρωτοβουλία καθόλου! Δεν είχανε οι μάνες τότε. Το βράδυ θα ερχόντουσαν για το αρραβώνιασμα. Αυτή σκεφτότανε μόνη της να φύγει, να πάει στις αδερφές και στους θείους της στη χώρα. Δεν είχε εκεί τις αδερφές της να τη παρηγορήσουνε, να συνεννοηθεί να δει, πώς θα πάει να φύγει. Αλλά αν έφευγε.. και το πρωί συναντιόταν ο γαμπρός με τα’ αδέρφια της; θα σκοτωνόντουσαν. Έτσι γινόταν τότε. Θα ‘λεγε ο γαμπρός «Μου την έδωσε και μετά της έδωσες και έφυγε;» Και αυτό τη σταμάτησε. Να μη σκοτωθεί ο αδερφός της. Καλός λέει ήτανε ο γαμπρός, είχε όνομα, ήτανε ωραίος άντρας, αλλά δεν ήτανε για αυτήν. Ούτε τον διάλεξε ούτε τη ρωτήσανε. Του ‘λεγε αυτή: «Γι ’άντα μ ’αγαπάς τόσο να πολύ;» Κάνανε 4 κοπέλια, ζήσανε μαζί και έμεινε χήρα 55 χρονώ. Τότε το πένθος ήτανε μεγάλη προίκα, δεν μπορούσες αλλιώς. Χρόνια κρατούσε! Μα αυτή δε το ‘βαλε το τσεμπέρι. Στην αρχή τηνε κατηγορήσανε που δε το ‘βαζε. Και οι γυναίκες και οι γειτόνισσες όλες. Αλλά δεν είδανε ότι αυτή τις έσωσε. Ήτανε η πρώτη που σταμάτησε και μπορούσανε μετά και άλλες και δε το βάζανε. Το ‘κανε αυτή πρώτη και σταμάτησε εκεί. Τις προάλλες πήγε και τηνέ βρήκε μια κοπέλα που ζει πέρα σε ένα κράτος και της λέγε: «Χθες κουβεντιάζαμε με τσ’ αδερφές μου στη Νέα Υόρκη και είπα το όνομά σου, πώς έκοψες το τσεμπέρι». Αυτό εκόπηκε τώρα, δε πα να φύγει ο άντρας είκοσι, δε πα να φύγει τριάντα, δε πα να φύγει σαράντα χρονών, δεν ξαναβάζουνε οι γυναίκες το μαντήλι. Τώρα, σε ένα χρόνο προχωρούνε. Ε τι να κάνεις; Έτσι είναι η ζωή, πρέπει να κοιτάξεις και την απατή σου. Και τι; Να το φοράνε οι γυναίκες και να δουλεύουνε (;) Παλιά, το πένθος κρατιόταν από τις γυναίκες. Οι πιο πολλοί άντρες κοιτούσαν πώς θα ξαναπαντρευτούνε. Αυτοί παντρευότανε όταν πέθαινε η γυναίκα τους. Παντρευότανε γιατί δε μπορούσαν μοναχοί. Οι γυναίκες δεν ξαναπαντρευόντουσαν και να φορούσαν και το τσεμπέρι! Άμα φορούσανε το τσεμπέρι δήλωνε ότι έχανε κλείσει, ότι είχαν τελειώσει. Αυτή η γυναίκα, 55 χρονών χήρεψε και από και κι μετά έκαμε ένα σωρό δουλειές. Σπούδασε τα παιδιά, έχτισε σπίτια, έκανε δουλειές και όλα αυτά από τη φτώχεια. Άλλες χηρεύανε είκοσι, είκοσι δυο, είκοσι πέντε χρονών και δεν ξαναπαντρευόντουσαν. Εδά, σε κάνα άδικο χαμό οι παλιές ρωτάνε: έβαλε η χήρα το τσεμπέρι; Έννοια το ‘χουνε να πάνε να της το βγάλουνε και αυτές που δε το βάλανε και αυτές που το φορούνε.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: My mother had me wear the chemberi, when I was 10 years old. The nazi occupation orphaned me. My mother used to tell me, “You don't have a father, you will put the chemberi on”. While I was at school the teachers would remove it from my head. Back at home, when I was changing clothes, my mother would put it back on tightly. I did love my father very much. I will never forget that time when I was in the second grade of primary school, and I was appointed to dance first in the circle, along with the fourth, the fifth, and the sixth grade. The teacher told me "You will come that day for the rehearsal. And when we will all dance at the square, you will lead the circle!” I stood still and asked, “me?” She said, "You will! You will come! I know you; you dance well, you will come!” And I had my late father, who was a grocer, going to the city every now and then, and he bought me a nice dress, a red one, and also shiny leather shoes and ankle socks. The day comes for us to go dance at the square. And I take my place at the head of the circle. We didn't have lyras then, no instruments at all, we would only sing along. With our little song we would manage to get into the rhythm and to synchronize our steps, while dancing. I come forward, I lead the dance, we dance, end of story. My late father and my mother at the square were sitting at the front. I will never forget it. As soon as the dance was over, my father took me in his arms, placed me on his lap and told me: “To this day, never have I ever experienced such joy in my life.” This is what I remember. My father was one of the first who was killed in the town during the nazi occupation. My mother was in great grief. At that time, all women were losing their loved ones - I don’t say no- but she lost her husband, and six months later, her brother too. The things she did were extremely grave… She painted the house black, the linen, the sheets, everything. When the Germans burned our village down, we moved to the town. We had our uncle and aunt there, who devoted their lives with great sacrifices to raising their brother's orphans. There, I went back to school, again. I was still wearing the chemberi and people were feeling sorry for me. My teacher told me, "Come to the office, I want to talk to you". I went, I found my teacher there and she had a little dress wrapped inside a newspaper. Back then they had sent shoes and clothes for the refugee children. And the teacher told me, "I saw a little dress and it fits you just fine, I have kept it for you". She wrapped it in the newspaper and handed it over to me. I still remember it, I remember the colours. It was blue with white flowers on it. As soon as I saw it, I was filled with joy! I thought,”‘ah, it’s time to wear something else!”. And she told me, “Τake it to your mom to get it washed and ironed, so you come with it to the first rehearsal. And in the next rehearsal you will say the dialogue”, we used to call the poems “dialogue” back then. And I take the little dress, I give it to my mom, and I say, “Mum, my teacher gave me this little dress, please get it washed and ironed so I put it on the other day, when I will say the dialogue”. And what did she do? She went and took black dye. She coloured the dress black. She did not even utter a word to me, nothing. In a couple of days, I told her, “Hey mum, please get my dress ironed, because the time comes for me to wear it”. She replied, “the dress is ready”. I saw it and I bet that moment I lost my mind. “It does not matter, my child. How were you meant to go and recite the poem while wearing a dress decorated with flowers? You don't have a dad”. I took it and went for the rehearsal. The teacher saw me and screamed. “It doesn't matter”, I said, ”since I don't have a dad, it doesn't matter”. Well, I wore the dyed dress and I recited the poem. I can’t recall if I ever took the chemberi off. After a long time, when I was older, I started wearing it this way at the back of my head, like a net, as we say. Because the nazi occupation had orphaned me, but later the junta regime left me without a husband, either. Gestapo officers, my child, had murdered the most. Tough years. Anyone who has not been through a war should never say that has known hardship. At that time, we lived with fear and terror. My husband fought in the resistance against the nazi occupation and died during the dictatorship. He had been so brutally tortured by the police, that within a year he died. I was thirty-eight years old, and I lost the world. We had seven children. It was a heavy load, my child. My mother helped me and so did my aunt again, my sisters-in-law, my mother-in-law, they all helped to raise the children together. So, I wear the chemberi again following the standard. Since then, I haven't taken it off, nor I am planning to. This time around that I am an old woman will l take my chemberi off? The strangers, when they were seeing me, back then being a young woman and wearing the chemberi, they were feeling pity for me. I have a photograph from that time with me and my mother, both wearing the chemberi. My mother when she would look at the photograph was saying “who are who and who is me?”. Wearing the chemberi equals declaring that you are done. Well, for my husband’s sake, I did not care about being done. It is only because you asked me that I am telling you all this. Otherwise, I never want to talk about my hardships. My nature is to be with a smile on my face. People who pass by ask me, “aunty, is everything all right? Are all the problems solved?”. I have solved everything; I don't have any problem. Should you have any, you go and solve it too. The chemberi is now over and this is a good thing. What does it mean if you don’t wear it? That you don't remember your husband? It's not this. No. Even if you put a red dress on, inside you nothing changes. And to those women, who never wore it, I take my hat off. I do take my hat off to them, my child. Because I say, ok one has died, why should the other be sentenced too? Despite me having been sentenced first. Other women were widowed at the age of twenty, twenty-two, twenty-five and would never marry again. Nowadays, in the case of a man’s early death the older women ask: did the widow put the chemberi on? Both those of them who didn't wear it and those who wear it, are keen to go and have it removed from her.

binding.name: o
binding.literal:
Εμένα μου ‘βαλε η μάνα μου το τσεμπέρι όντε ήμουνα 10 χρονώ. Η κατοχή με ορφάνεψε. Μου ‘λεγε η μάνα μου «δεν έχεις πατέρα, θα βάνεις το τσεμπέρι». Επήγαινα στο σκολείο, μου το βγάνανε οι δασκάλες. Να αλλάσω σπίτι, να μου το βάνει η μάνα μου έτσα σφιχτά σφιχτά.
Τον πατέρα μου τον αγαπούσα πολύ. Δε θα ξεχάσω μια φορά που ήμουνε στη δευτέρα τάξη του δημοτικού, που με βάνουνε να χορέψω πρώτη, μαζί με την Τετάρτη, Πέμπτη και Έκτη. Και ‘θελα μου πει η δασκάλα «γιάε! θα ΄ρθεις την τάδε μέρα που θα κάνομαι πρόβες, να σύρεις εσύ το χορό στην πλατεία. Επάγωσα. Λέω. «εγώ;» Μου λέει «θα ‘ρθεις, θα ΄ρθεις! Σε ξέρω, χορεύεις ωραία, θα ρθεις!» Και είχα το συγχωρεμένο τον πατέρα μου, που ήτανε μπακάλης και κατέβαινε κάθε τόσο στη χώρα και μου παίρνει ένα ωραίο φορεματάκι, ένα κόκκινο φορεματάκι με λουστρινένια παπουτσάκια και σοσονάκια. Έρχεται η μέρα να πάμε στην πλατεία, να χορέψομε. Και μπαίνω εγώ στην πρώτη μεριά, δεν είχαμε τότε λύρες, πράμα, ελέγαμε τραγουδάκια. Με το τραγουδάκι συνεννοούμασταν και με τα βήματα του χορού εχορεύαμε. Μπαίνω εγώ μπροστά, σύρνω το χορό, χορεύουμε, τελειώνει η ιστορία. Ο μακαρίτης ο πατέρας μου με τη μάνα μου καθότανε μπροστά μπροστά. Δε θα το ξεχάσω ποτέ αυτό το πράμα. Μόλις ετελείωσε ο χορός, με παίρνει στην αγκαλιά του και με βάνει στα πόδια του και μου λέει: «Δεν είδα μεγαλύτερη χαρά στη ζωή μου ‘σάμε αυτή τη μέρα» αυτό θυμούμαι. Ο πατέρας μου επόθανε από τσοι πρώτους που επέσανε στη χώρα στην κατοχή. Η μάνα μου ήτανε βαρυπενθούσα. Όλες εχάνανε τότε τσοι δικούς τους, δε λέω, αλλά αυτή έχασε τον άντρα της, και σε εξε μήνες μέσα και έναν αδερφό και αυτά που έκαμε ήτονε πολύ βαριά. Έβαφε το σπίτι μαύρο, τα πανιά, τα σεντόνια, όλα. Όντε κάψανε το χωριό οι Γερμανοί, εμείς επήγαμε στη χώρα. Είχαμε το θείο και τη θεία, που εθυσιαστήκανε για να μεγαλώσουνε τα ορφανά του αδερφού τους. Εκειά ξαναπήγα στο σκολειό, στη χώρα. Ακόμα φορούσα το τσεμπέρι και με λυπούντανε. Μου λέει η δασκάλα, «Να ‘ρθεις στο γραφείο που σε θέλω». Και πάω εγώ, βρίνω τη δασκάλα που με διάβαζε, και είχε σε μια εφημερίδα ένα φορεματάκι τυλιγμένο. Είχανε στείλει τότε, ενδυμασίες, παπούτσα ρούχα για τα προσφυγάκια. Και μου λέει «εγώ είδα ένα φορεματάκι και σου κάνει ίσα ίσα και στο φυλάγω». Το τυλίσει σε μια εφημερίδα και μου το δίνει. Ακόμα το θυμάμαι, θυμούμαι τα χρώματα. Ήτονε μπλε, με άσπρα λουλουδάκια. Εγώ ‘σαμε να το ειδώ εχάρηκα! Να βάλω λεω, να φορέσω και κάτι άλλο!.. Και μου λέει «Α το πας στη μαμά σου να στο πλύνει, να το σιδερώσει, να ΄ρθεις στην πρώτη πρόβα. Και στην άλλη πρόβα θα πεις τον διάλογο», διάλογο το λέγαμε τοτεσας. Και παίρνω το φορεματάκι, το πάω στη μαμά, της λέω, «μάνα η δασκάλα μου ‘δωκε αυτό το φορεματάκι να μου το πλύνεις, να μου το σιδερώσεις, να το βάλω την άλλη μέρα που θα πω τον διάλογο». Και τι κάνει αυτή; Πάει και παίρνει μπογιά μαύρη. Βάφει το φορεματάκι. Δε μου λέει εμένα κουβέντα, τίποτα.
Σε δυο τρεις μέρες της λέω «ε μα’, το φορεματάκι να μου σιδερώσεις γιατί πρέπει να το βάλω». Μου λέει, «έτοιμο το φορεματάκι». Το βλέπω, μα πρέπει να εποχάυρισα. «Δε πειράζει παιδί μου! Πώς θελα πας εδά με τα λουλούδάκια να πεις το ποίημα; Δεν έχεις μπαμπά.» Το βάνω, πάω να κάνουμε τη πρόβα, με βλέπει η δασκάλα και ούρλιασε. «Δε πειράζει της λέω εγώ, αφού δεν έχω μπαμπά, δεν πειράζει». Ε, έβαλα το φορεματάκι βαμμένο και είπα το ποίημα. Δεν θυμούμαι καλά ανε το ‘βγαλα ποτέ το τσεμπέρι. Μετά από χρόνους που μεγάλωσα το φόρουνα έτσι ποπίσω, σα τον φιλέ που λέμε. Γιατί μετά.. η κατοχή με ορφάνεψε, μα η χούντα με χήρεψε. Οι γκεσταμπήτες παιδί μου, εφάγανε τσι πια πολλούς αθρώπους. Δύσκολα χρόνια. Όποιος δεν έχει ζήσει πόλεμο να μη λέει πως είδε ζόρε, με τον φόβο και τον τρόμο ζούσαμε. Ο άντρας μου ήτανε στην αντίσταση στην κατοχή και ‘πόθανε στη Χούντα. Είχε κόψει το αίμα του από τους βασανισμούς που του κάνανε στην ασφάλεια και σε ένα χρόνο μέσα επόθανε. Τριάντα οκτώ χρονώ ήμουνα. Και έχασα τον κόσμο. Είχαμε 7 κοπέλια. Βαρύ φορτίο παιδί μου. Με βοήθησε η μάνα μου, η θεία πάλι, η κουνιάδες μου, η πεθερά μου, συντράμανε όλες να μεγαλώσομε τα κοπέλια. Έτσα, ξαναβάνω το τσεμπέρι κανονικά. Και δε το ‘χω βγάλει και ούτε πρόκειται. Εδά που εμεγάλωσα θελα να βγάλω το τσεμπέρι; Όντε με βλέπανε νέα γυναίκα με λυπούντανε οι ξένοι που θελα ΄ρθούνε. Έχω μια φωτογραφία από τότε, που ‘μαι με τη μάνα μου, και φορούμε και οι δυο το τσεμπέρι. Την έβλεπε και μου λεγε, «μωρε συ, μα ποια είσαι εσύ και ποια είμαι εγώ;» Άμα το βάλεις είναι σα να λες ετελείωσα και γώ. Αλλά για χατίρι του αντρούς μου δε με ‘νοιαζε να τελειώσω. Αυτά εδά σας τα λέω γιατί μ’ ερωτήξατε. Αλλιώς δε θέλω να λέω να βάσανά μου ποτέ, και είμαι σαφή με το χαμόγελο. Έτσα είναι η καμωσά μου. Περνάνε οι αθρώποι και με ρωτούνε «Θεία όλα καλα; Τα λύσαμε όλα τα προβλήματα;» Όλα τα ‘χω λύσει, δεν έχω κανένα πρόβλημα, μόνο εσείς αμα νεχετε να τα λύνετε και εσείς. Το τσεμπέρι τώρα το κόψανε τελείως και καλά το κάμανε. Δηλαδή άμα δε το φορείς τι σημαίνει; Ότι δεν τον θυμάσαι τον άντρα σου; Δεν είναι αυτό. Όχι. Και ένα κόκκινο φόρεμα να βάλεις, μέσα σου δεν αλλάσει τιποτα. Και αυτές που δε το βάλανε καθόλου τονε βγάνω το καπέλο. Εγώ τονε βγάνω το καπέλο παιδί μου. Γιατί λέω επόθανε ο εις, να μη καταδικαστεί μωρέ και ο άλλος. Κι ας είμαι εγώ πρώτη που εκαταδικάστηκα. Άλλες χηρεύανε είκοσι, εικοσι-δυο, εικοσιπέντε χρονών και δεν ξαναπαντρευόντουσαν. Εδά, σε κάνα άδικο χαμό οι παλιές ρωτάνε: έβαλε η χήρα το τσεμπέρι; Έννοια το ‘χουνε να πάνε να της το βγάλουνε και αυτές που δε το βάλανε και αυτές που το φορούνε.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: In the late 1800s, when Crete became a state and the Turkish army left, a lot of things started changing quickly. This affected who lived in the city of Heraklion and the countryside, making the population look different than before.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: When the island gave more control to itself because the Christian people wanted it, many Muslims felt uncertain and unsafe. This led to a lot of them leaving. Around 50,000 Muslims left Crete between 1896 and 1899, going to places like the Ottoman Empire, Asia Minor, Rhodes, Kos, and other parts of the Eastern Mediterranean. Even though the Cretan State said everyone should be treated the same and could practice their religion freely, only a few Muslims came back. Instead, more of them kept leaving, especially in the early 1900s. In the Heraklion area alone, from 1900 to 1909, 2,455 out of 3,091 Muslims left the whole island.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Because of the same reasons, more Muslim people started living in the safe, protected cities of the island. This happened because they felt unsure, and many of them left the countryside.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: In the year 1900, according to the 'General Census of the Island,' the city of Heraklion and its nearby areas had 22,481 people. Among them, 11,659 were Muslims, 10,753 were Christians, and 69 were "Israelites." Even though Muslims were more in number in the city, their proportion in the total population had gone down significantly. This trend continued in the next years. In the 'Census of the population of the island on June 4-5, 1911,' the Muslim population decreased, and the ratio compared to the Christian population flipped. In the urban Municipality of Heraklion, out of 25,185 people, Christians were 15,877, Muslims were only 9,248, and there were 60 Israelites.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: When we look closely at the data from the 1900 census and consider what we know from history, we see changes in the rural areas around Heraklion too. The big change is the significant drop in the total number of Muslims compared to the census of 1881. Some places where only Muslims lived became empty, and in areas where both Muslims and Christians lived, the number of Muslims, especially women, went down quickly.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: As per N. Andriotis, the number of Muslims in Crete went down by half, precisely 53.7%, from 1881 to 1900. Their part in the total population also dropped from 25.9% in 1881 to 11% in 1900. The Muslim population in the three major cities only decreased by 13%. In 1900, Muslims were still the majority in the cities of Heraklion and Rethymno. However, in the rural areas, the Muslim population had a significant decrease, by 83.5%, going from 18% of the total rural population in 1881 to only 2.8% in 1900.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: During this time, many people from Crete, both Christians and Muslims, moved overseas and to faraway places. Tough economic conditions and ongoing conflicts, along with the global economic situation, made life uncertain. The need for workers in growing economies in Western Europe and America led a significant number of Cretans to leave their home. According to Lena Tzedaki-Apostolaki, 'in the early 1900s, 10,620 people, which is about 3.5% of the island's population, left Crete for different countries worldwide.' Most of them went to Europe and America, and a few to Oceania, especially Christian immigrants who make up 70% of the total. It's interesting to note that those going to the United States were mostly young males, unlike movements to other places that often involved families.

binding.name: o
binding.literal: Apart from moving to other countries, a new way that people moved during this time started to shape the city's population and its social and cultural traits. Workers, especially women, began moving from Christian villages to the city. They did this either permanently or for a part of the year to find jobs, mostly in the growing soap industry. Additionally, many worked in the first raisin processing plants that were just starting to be set up.

binding.name: o
binding.literal:
Studying the people who lived in Heraklion and its surrounding area from the late 1800s to the early 1900s is connected to the political changes and resulting shifts in the economy and society. It's important to grasp and explain the city's population changes in the context of larger events in Crete, the Balkans, and the Eastern Mediterranean.
Getting the exact number of people living in that time is tricky because the information mainly comes from administrative reports, diplomatic records, estimates by travelers, and historians. The records from the 19th century don't follow today's census standards, making it hard to compare. Besides the post-1913 censuses after Crete united with Greece, only the ones in 1881 and 1900 give us important and systematic data with comparable figures.
All the records and censuses, even if not entirely precise, offer qualitative details. When combined with historical research, they help us not just understand changes in population numbers but also movements, makeup, and structural shifts in the people living in and around Heraklion

binding.name: o
binding.literal:
People in Crete really wanted to join Greece. Everyone, including the important leader and different political groups, shared this goal. But, there was a problem.
